questions.solution:
Explanation:

A strawberry cervix, or an angry-looking cervix, is seen in cases of Trichomonas infection due to punctate haemorrhages in the cervix.

Trichomonas vaginitis:

  • Profuse frothy greenish yellow discharge
  • Urinary symptoms
  • Dyspareunia
  • Strawberry cervix or angry-looking cervix

  • Saline microscopy -Typical motile flagellated trichomonads are seen

  • Trichomonas does not have a cyst form; it exists solely as a trophozoite, the active, motile form of the parasite.

Explanation for other options:

Candida albicans (Option A): Causes thick white discharge and itching, but not a strawberry cervix.

Gardnerella vaginalis (H. vaginalis) (Option B): Causes bacterial vaginosis with thin grey discharge and fishy odour, not strawberry cervix.

Syphilis (Option C): Causes painless ulcers (chancres) and systemic signs, not a strawberry cervix.

questions.text: In hysterosalpingography, fallopian tubes are seen beaded in appearance with clubbing of the fimbrial end and ampulla. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

HSG showing 'Bead-like fallopian tube and clubbing of ampulla are suggestive of genital tuberculosis'

HSG findings in the case of tuberculosis:

A rigid, non-peristaltic pipe-like tube with a lead pipe appearance.

  • Beading of the tube and variation in filling density.
  • Elongated and distended tube with everted fimbriae and patent abdominal ostium, called 'tobacco pouch' appearance.
  • Calcification of the tube, Bilateral cornual block.
  • Vascular or lymphatic intravasation of dye.
  • Tubal diverticula
  • Uterine cavity - irregular outline, honeycomb appearance or presence of uterine synechiae (Asherman's syndrome).

In a proven case of genital tuberculosis, HSG is contraindicated as it may spread the infection. So, HSG should not be performed until pelvic tuberculosis is excluded by endometrial study.

The most common route of spread in genital TB is hematogenous.

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient is having discharge per vagina, evaluated and on endocervical biopsy Chlamydia was found. What would be the appropriate treatment measure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Azithromycin and contact tracing would be the appropriate steps in treatment.

Management of Chlamydia

Uncomplicated chlamydia can be treated with

  • Tetracycline (500 mg 4 times daily),
  • Doxycycline (1000 mg twice daily),
  • Erythromycin (500 mg 4 times daily),
  • Fluoroquinolone-ofloxacin 300 mg twice daily, or
  • Azithromycin (single dose) - 1 g

Advantages of Azithromycin

  • Single dose regimen - 1 g stat dose (It is as effective as 7 days of doxycycline treatment).
  • Better patient compliance.
  • Fewer gastrointestinal side effects.

Contact tracing:

  • Patients with asymptomatic infection and their sex partners form a major burden of chlamydial infection, so contact tracing should always be done wherever possible.

questions.text: A 22-year-old female with a history of multiple sexual contacts presented with growth on the vulva for 2 months; the probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Multiple sexual contacts with growth on the vulva are symptoms of condyloma acuminata.

Condyloma Acuminata

  • Cause: Human Papillomavirus (HPV), mainly types 6 and 11 (low-risk); sometimes misattributed to 16 and 18 (which are high-risk, oncogenic types).
  • Transmission: Sexually transmitted infection.
  • Lesion Features:
    • Warty, verrucous growths in areas most affected by coitus: posterior fourchette, lateral vulva, and perineum.
    • May coalesce into large cauliflower-like masses.
  • Oncogenic Risk: Associated with vulval, vaginal, and cervical cancers, especially when high-risk HPV (16, 18) is involved.

Explanation for other options:

Verruca plana (Option B): Flat warts, usually seen on the face or hands, not in the genital region.

Verruca vulgaris (Option C): Common warts, typically keratotic and found on hands, elbows, not genitals, caused by other HPV strains (like 1, 2, 4).

Condyloma lata (Option D): Seen in secondary syphilis, flat, moist, and highly infectious lesions.

  • Observation: In young or pregnant women with flat warts, observation for up to 6 months may be considered, as spontaneous resolution can occur.

questions.text: The preferred site for obtaining cultures in a patient with acute PID during laparotomy is,
questions.solution:
Explanation:

During laparotomy, the preferred site for obtaining cultures in acute PID is the fallopian tubes.

For the identification of organisms in Pelvic Inflammatory Disease, the materials are collected from the following available sources:

  • Discharge from the urethra or Bartholin's gland
  • Cervical canal
  • Collected pus from the fallopian tubes during laparoscopy or laparotomy.

The material collected is subjected to Gram's stain and culture (aerobic/anaerobic). The findings of Gram-negative diplococci are suggestive of gonococcal infection.

questions.text: All are risk factors for vaginal candidiasis except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hypertension is not a risk factor for vaginal candidiasis.

Risk Factors for Candida (Monilla) Vaginitis

  • Promiscuity/multiple sex partners
  • Immunosuppression (like HIV) (Option A)
  • Pregnancy (Option C)
  • Steroid therapy
  • Following long-term broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy
  • Oral contraceptive pills
  • Diabetes mellitus (Option D)
  • Poor personal hygiene
  • Obesity

choices.text: Mycobacterium can be grown from menstrual blood

questions.text: In a patient with pelvic inflammatory disease due to tuberculosis, which of the following statements is not true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Dysmenorrhea is not a common presentation of PID due to tuberculosis.

The most common presentations of genital tuberculosis include:

  • Infertility - Most common presentation due to tubal occlusion, endometrial scarring.
  • Chronic pelvic pain - Due to pelvic inflammation and adhesions.
  • Menstrual irregularities- Includes amenorrhea, oligomenorrhea, or menorrhagia.
  • Constitutional symptoms- Weight loss, fever, fatigue (less frequent).

Explanation for other options:

Mycobacterium can be grown from menstrual blood (Option A), especially during active disease.

Associated with infertility (Option B): Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) due to tuberculosis can lead to scarring and damage to the reproductive organs, causing infertility. Seen in up to 60-80% of GTB cases.

Ectopic pregnancy is common (Option C): Tuberculosis-related PID can increase the risk of ectopic pregnancies due to tubal damage and adhesions.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman approaches a physician for contraceptive advice. On examination, there were two symmetrical ulcers on the vulva, which were well-defined with a firm base. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Painless, well-defined ulcers with a firm base should raise the suspicion of a chancre.

Chancre is the primary lesion of primary syphilis.

  • It is most commonly found on the labium majus, labium minus, fourchette, clitoris, urethral orifice or cervix, but can be found anywhere on the lower genital tract.
  • In 10% cases, more than one primary lesion is present.
  • The first manifestation is a small papule that breaks to form an ulcer.
  • Any sort of discrete, relatively painless ulceration on the vulva may be a primary syphilitic lesion.
  • Inguinal glands enlarge when the primary is on the vulva or lower vagina.

Malignancy (Option D):

Chronic, non-healing ulcer, often irregular and possibly indurated, but less likely to appear suddenly as symmetrical, clean ulcers.

questions.text: Acute PID is treated by all except;
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Abdominal hysterectomy is not preferred for acute PID

Management of PID:

  • Broad-spectrum antibiotics (oral or IV) (Option A)
  • If a tubo-ovarian mass/abscess is present, it should be treated medically, but if there is no response, drainage should be done. (Option B)
  • Drainage of a pelvic abscess by colpotomy may occasionally be needed.
  • Laparoscopic exploration may be used in cases of acute PID to assess the extent of the infection and address complications such as tubo-ovarian abscesses. (Option D)

Conservative management with antibiotics and, if necessary, surgical intervention to address complications is typically considered first.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about trichomonas?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Strawberry vagina/cervix is a term used in Trichomonas to describe the appearance of the cervical mucosa with red, punctate hemorrhagic spots on the cervix.

  • Pregnant women with Trichomonas vaginitis are at increased risk for premature rupture of membranes and preterm delivery.
  • Treatment with oral doxycycline, 100 mg twice daily for 7 days, has been shown to increase the pregnancy rate in patients with primary infertility caused by genitourinary infections.

Explanation for other options:

Abortion (Option A): Trichomonas infection is not typically associated with abortion. However, it can cause complications during pregnancy, such as preterm birth and premature rupture of membranes.

Vaginal pH is 4 (Option B): Trichomonas infection is associated with an elevated vaginal pH, typically greater than 4.5.

Infertility (Option D): While trichomoniasis can cause discomfort and irritation, it is not a common cause of infertility

Common infections associated with infertility are:

  • Chlamydia trachomatis
  • N.gonorrhoeae
  • Ureoplasma ureolyticum

choices.text: Culture on chocolate agar supplemented with hemin
Culture on a bilayer human blood agar

questions.text: A 44-year-old female complains of lower abdominal pain and vaginal discharge. On examination, there is cervicitis along with a mucopurulent cervical discharge. The Gram smear of the discharge shows presence of abundant pus cells, but no bacteria. The best approach to isolate the possible causative agent would be:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Culture on McCoy cells would be the best approach to isolate the possible causative agent, as

  • Patient is complaining of abdominal pain and vaginal discharge.
  • On examination, cervicitis and mucopurulent discharge are seen, which indicates she is having PID.
  • The presence of pus cells in the absence of an organism indicates chlamydial infection, the most common STD nowadays.
  • It is an intracellular organism that grows only on McCoy or HeLa cell cultures.
  • It cannot be grown on other media and hence, often goes unnoticed, later leading to infertility.
  • Culture in McCoy cells is 100% specific for chlamydia, but is inexpensive, technically difficult and takes 3-7 days to obtain the result.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl came with a history of a painless ulcer in the labia majora with everted margins. The probable cause would be:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Painless ulcers in the labia majora with everted margins are suggestive of infection due to Treponema pallidum.

The most common causes of genital ulcers in young, sexually active women are:

  • Herpes simplex virus (HSV)
  • Treponema pallidum (syphilis)
  • Haemophilus ducreyi (chancroid)

questions.text: A 30-years-old lady presented with complaints of creamy white vaginal discharge with fishy odor. What would be the drug of choice?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The drug of choice for the management of bacterial vaginosis/Gardnerella vaginitis is Metronidazole.

  • Creamy white discharge with fishy odour is characteristic of bacterial vaginosis (most common cause: Gardnerella)
  • Dose - 500 mg oral metronidazole is given twice daily for 7 days (alternatively)
  • Metronidazole gel can be applied once daily for 5 days or
  • Clindamycin cream (2%) at bedtime for 5 days.
  • Treatment of the male sexual partner is not required in bacterial vaginosis.

In pregnancy:

  • Bacterial vaginosis is associated with preterm birth and premature rupture of membranes.
  • Treatment is reserved for symptomatic women who usually complain of a fishy odour.
  • DOC - Metronidazole (oral) in the 2nd and the 3rd trimester.

Syndromic Management of STI (NACO STI/RTI Kits)

choices.text: Ovarian involvement can occur without tubal affection
Infertility is mainly due to anovulation
C) Acid-fast bacilli are identified in 100% cases of tubercular endometritis
D) A negative Mantoux test reasonably excludes tuberculosis

questions.text: Which of the following is true about genital tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In genital tuberculosis, a negative Mantoux test reasonably excludes tuberculosis.

Purpose and Principle:

  • The Mantoux test is a diagnostic tool used to screen for latent or active tuberculosis (TB) infection.
  • It works on the principle of delayed-type (Type IV) hypersensitivity, where previously sensitised T-cells react to the injected antigen.
  • It indicates past or current exposure to Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

Procedure:

  • Intradermal injection of 0.1 mL of PPD (Purified Protein Derivative)
  • Common site: volar aspect of the forearm
  • Read after 48-72 hours

Interpretation:

  • An induration of ≥5 mm is positive in high-risk individuals like HIV patients or recent TB contacts.
  • An induration of ≥10 mm is positive in healthcare workers and vulnerable populations.
  • An induration of ≥15 mm is considered positive in healthy people with no known TB risk factors.

Limitations:

  • False Negative: Immunosuppression, recent TB infection, very old TB, viral illness
  • False Positive: Prior BCG vaccination, non-tuberculous mycobacteria

Explanation for other options:

Ovarian involvement can occur without tubal affection (Option A):Incorrect, as ovaries do not get involved without tubes being affected

Infertility is mainly due to anovulation (Option B): Incorrect, as infertility is mainly due to tubal blockage or adhesion in the endometrial cavity.

Acid-fast bacilli are identified in 100% of cases of TB endometritis (Option C): Incorrect, as acid-fast bacilli are not always identified in cases of tubercular endometritis; diagnosis often relies on histopathology and clinical findings.s

  • Salpingitis isthmica nodosa is the nodular thickening of the tube due to proliferation of tubal epithelium within the hypertrophied myosalpinx (muscle layer).
  • It is diagnosed radiologically as a small diverticulum. It is, however, not specific to tubercular infection only. It is also observed in pelvic endometriosis.

questions.text: The following are the primary sites of acute gonococcal infection except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The ectocervix is covered by squamous epithelium, and squamous epithelium is resistant to Gonococcal infection.

Primary genital sites of involvement of gonorrhea :

  • Endocervix
  • Urethra (Option A)
  • Skene's gland (Option C)
  • Bartholin's gland (Option B)

questions.text: Asymptomatic carriage of gonococcal infection in females is commonly seen in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Asymptomatic carriage of gonococcal infection in females is commonly seen in the endocervix

For the identification of organisms in PID, the materials are collected from the following available sources:

  • Discharge from the urethra or Bartholin's gland
  • Cervical canal
  • Collected pus from the fallopian tubes during laparoscopy or laparotomy.

The material collected is subjected to Gram's stain and culture (aerobic/anaerobic). The findings of Gram-negative diplococci are very much suggestive of gonococcal infection.

There are 2 important points which we should remember about the gonorrhoea infection.

  • Squamous epithelium is resistant to gonococcal infection
  • Gonorrhoea is an STD (i.e. it is transmitted by ascending infection along with sperms) Now, since squamous epithelium is resistant to gonococcal infection, in vagina and ectocervix gonococcal infection cannot occur (as both are lined by squamous epithelium).

choices.text: Genital tract involvement results from lymphatic spread
Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) techniques have higher sensitivity in detection
Reproductive outcome following antituberculous chemotherapy is satisfactory

questions.text: True statement about female genital tuberculosis:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

PCR is more sensitive (85-95%) than microscopy and bacteriological culture in the diagnosis of genital tuberculosis.

  • Genital tuberculosis is usually secondary to primary infection (lungs, bones, lymph nodes).
  • It spreads by haematogenous route (not lymphatic route), leading to endosalpingitis.
  • Caseous granulomatous lesions with giant cells on pathological examination are suggestive of TB, but are not diagnostic, as they can also be seen in fungal infection.
  • Sarcoidosis shows characteristically non casseous granulomas.
  • The PCR method can detect fewer than 10 organisms in clinical specimens compared to 10,000 necessary for smear positivity.
  • The reproductive outcome, even after treatment, is poor.
  • The pregnancy rate is about 20%, live birth rate is only 7%.
  • The risk of miscarriage and ectopic pregnancy is high.

questions.text: Drug of choice for Chlamydia in pregnancy:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Azithromycin is the first-line treatment and has been found to be safe and efficacious in pregnancy.

  • DOC for Chlamydia trachomatis infection = Azithromycin
  • Treatment of chlamydia infection during pregnancy
  • Preferred choice- Azithromycin (1 g) as a single dose or Amoxicillin (500 mg) orally 3 times a day × 7 days
  • Doxycycline and Tetracycline are contraindicated in pregnancy due to the risks of fetal tooth discolouration and bone growth inhibition.
  • Erythromycin is an alternative, but it requires multiple doses and is associated with more GI side effects.

choices.text: Menstruating teenagers who have multiple sex partners
Women with a monogamous partner who had a vasectomy

questions.text: The risk factors of acute pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) are the following, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Women with a monogamous partner who had a vasectomy are a protective factor for PID and not a risk factor.

Risk factors of PID:

  • Menstruating teenagers. (Option A)
  • Multiple sexual partners. (Option A)
  • Absence of contraceptive pill use.
  • Previous history of acute PID. (Option D)
  • IUD users. (Option B)
  • Area with a high prevalence of sexually transmitted diseases

Protective factors of PID:

Contraceptive practice

  • Barrier methods, especially condoms, diaphragms with spermicides
  • Oral steroidal contraceptives have two preventive aspects. Produce a thick mucus plug, preventing the ascent of sperm and bacterial penetration
  • A decrease in the duration of menstruation creates a shorter interval of bacterial colonisation of the upper tract.
  • Monogamy or having a partner who has had a vasectomy
